subject: Re: [junit] help please?
msgSnippet: ... But that doesn t communicate the intent.  You might write it better as: assertTrue( we want this line to fail because , 2
messageBody:
On Monday 23 August 2004 04:12 am, santu nand wrote:
> Hi Peter,
> Thanks a lot.
>
>
> But i have a doubt.Instead of fail in the below exampe we can also write
>
> AssertTrue(2<1); //This will always fail.

But that doesn't communicate the intent. You might write it better as:
assertTrue("we want this line to fail because <blah>", 2 < 1);

However, if I came across that in code I would wonder why in the world I had
to cobble something together like that. "Why doesn't the framework just let
me fail?" would be my question. If you look at the code in Assert.java you
will find fail(...) used over and over again because it is communicating the
intent, not an accident. It also removes duplication -- whereas I would have
to send some bogus "assert" message anytime I wanted to fail or manually
throw a new AssertionFailedError all over the place. The conclusion I come
to is that fail(...) makes the code cleaner and easier to read.

--
